title: Pammene rhediella
text:
Pammene rhediella is a <a href="moth">moth</a> belonging to the family <a href="Tortricidae">Tortricidae</a>. The species was <a href="species%20description">first described</a> by <a href="Carl%20Alexander%20Clerck">Carl Alexander Clerck</a> in 1759.
It is native to Europe. and across the <a href="Palearctic">Palearctic</a>.
The wingspan is 9-12 millimeter. The forewings are dark fuscous. The central fascia is darker and ferruginous-tinged and the apical area beyond this wholly deep ferruginous-orange, with leaden-metallic spots and striae. The hindwings fuscous, in males with a blackish spot on vein 1c towards the termen.
The larva develops in the flowers and fruits of shrubs and trees in the rose family, most often on <a href="Crataegus%20monogyna">hawthorn</a> but occasionally also on apple and pear. The adults fly in May-June, most during the day in hot sunshine over the tops of hawthorn-trees. Since the species' main nutrient plant is hawthorn, it is usually not considered a problematic pest, but if it attacks fruit trees it can do significant damage.
